div1.p: Louise Kean writes about cases of yellow fever and news of the family.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, November 25, 1900
div1.p:
Mrs. Stark and I
are wondering what
you have done about
my last letter, and
if it bothered you
very much to do our
christmas shopping. I
think we are looking
forward to opening
the box as much as the
children are to Christmas.
It does seem as if
we would never set
tle down to a really
quiet sedate life! The
Dunns left us Monday
so Rufinia is now
cooking for the Slocum's
and ourselves, but Major
Rolfe is to come in in
a day or two, Col. Bur-
ton at the end of
the month and his
wife and daughters
just before Christmas.
Rannie has become a
“commuter” these days.
He has to go into
Havana every morning and does not
get back until the half past four
train. His office is in Gen. Ludlow's
old house. The other day Martha
and I drove in for him. (We have
the victoria, a pair of black horses
and the faithful Bourette) I intended
to call on Mrs. Ladd, who is living
upstairs, when I got to the house
Rannie told me she had yellow
fever. She has what the doctors
call a “beautiful” case, all the symp-
toms will marked but not at all
severe, she has been given a white
certificate by the board, and Rannie
says she is very proud. We all
feel dreadfully about Capt. Cook's death
His poor wife only got here two
hours before he died. I knew them
the first winter we were here, and
I liked Mrs. Cook very much. She is
staying with the Gorgases-

I do hope Mase will come down with
Mama, for the fever
is really decreasing,
and we will take
such good care of him.
You know how perfectly
lovely Columbia is, and
we never think of
the fever everybody is
so well. Bobbie and
Martha are flourishing
like green bay trees.
I think Mr. Bobs will
have a tooth in a
couple of weeks. I have
gotten a Spanish dollar
with the baby Alfonso on
it. Rannie has bored a
hole in it and Bob
chews on it with
great joy. He can catch
hold of things pretty
well now, and he
knows his family by
sight I am sure- Emma
wants me to tell you
that he goes to sleep
for her just as he did
for you, tucks his little
head down on her
arm and shuts his
eyes. Emma is crazy
about him, in fact
everybody is who sees,
him he is so jolly
and friendly.

Tell Doll I am going to send her
her cap, but not being able to
go into town whenever I want
to delays the game very much.

Give a great deal of love to all
the family and tell allone of the girls
to write me all the news
